topic: Decision-Making, Peer Influence, and Protective Strategies
subject: Health and Physical Education

A.levelDescription: Basic understanding of how friends and social situations influence choices about drugs and alcohol.
whatYouWillLearn: How friends and social situations can influence decisions about drugs
The difference between helpful and unhelpful influences
Simple strategies for saying no when you feel uncomfortable
Who to talk to when you need help with a difficult situation

explicatoryContent.heading: How Friends Influence Our Choices
explicatoryContent.text: Friends have a big influence on the choices we make, including choices about drugs and alcohol. This can be positive or negative. Good friends can support us in making healthy choices and can be there for us when times are tough. Sometimes, though, we might feel pressure from friends to do things we are not comfortable with, including trying drugs or alcohol. This pressure might be obvious (someone directly asking you to try something) or more subtle (feeling left out if you do not join in). Understanding that this influence exists is the first step in making your own choices.

explicatoryContent.heading: Types of Peer Pressure
explicatoryContent.text: Peer pressure is the influence that people your age have on your decisions and behaviour. Direct pressure is when someone specifically asks or tells you to do something, like offering you a drink. Indirect pressure is when you feel you should do something because others are doing it, even if no one asks you directly. Sometimes people use put-downs or teasing to pressure others. True friends will respect your choices and will not pressure you to do things that make you uncomfortable or could harm you. If someone keeps pressuring you after you have said no, that is not respectful behaviour.

explicatoryContent.heading: Simple Ways to Say No
explicatoryContent.text: It can feel hard to say no, especially to friends, but there are ways to do it that can make it easier. You can give a simple excuse like 'No thanks, I have to get up early tomorrow' or 'I am on medication that I cannot mix with that.' You can suggest doing something else instead. You can use humour to lighten the situation. You can also just say 'No thanks' and not give a reason at all - you do not owe anyone an explanation. The key is to be clear and confident. Practice what you might say in advance so you feel prepared. If the pressure continues, it is okay to leave the situation or ask for help.

explicatoryContent.heading: Getting Help When You Need It
explicatoryContent.text: If you are in a situation involving drugs or alcohol that worries you, there are people who can help. Trusted adults like parents, guardians, teachers, or school counsellors can provide support and advice. If you are at a party or social event and feel unsafe, you can call a parent or trusted adult to pick you up without questions. There are also helplines you can call anonymously: Kids Helpline (1800 55 1800) and DirectLine (1800 888 236). In an emergency where someone's health is at risk, always call 000 for ambulance - you will not get in trouble for seeking help.

B.levelDescription: Developing understanding of social influences on decision-making and expanding repertoire of protective strategies.
whatYouWillLearn: How social situations and environments affect decision-making
The psychology behind why peer influence is so powerful during adolescence

How to support friends who might be struggling

explicatoryContent.heading: The Power of Social Influence
explicatoryContent.text: Humans are social creatures, and we are naturally influenced by the people around us. During adolescence, this influence becomes particularly strong because forming relationships and belonging to a group are important developmental tasks. Studies show that teenagers are more likely to take risks when peers are watching than when alone. This is not a flaw - it is part of how our brains develop. However, understanding this influence helps us make more conscious choices. Social influence is not always negative; friends can also positively influence us toward healthy behaviours, academic success, and pursuing our goals.

explicatoryContent.heading: Understanding Why We Feel Pressured
explicatoryContent.text: Several psychological factors make peer pressure powerful. Fear of rejection is strong during adolescence - we worry about losing friendships or social status. Conformity, or the desire to fit in with a group, is a natural human tendency. Sometimes we look to others to know how to behave in uncertain situations, which is called social proof. Media and advertising also influence our perceptions by making certain behaviours seem normal or desirable. Recognising these factors helps explain why saying no can feel so hard, even when we know what we want to do. It is not about being weak; it is about understanding normal human psychology.

explicatoryContent.heading: Expanding Your Toolkit for Handling Pressure
explicatoryContent.text: Different situations call for different strategies. Assertive refusal involves clearly stating your position with confidence: 'No, I have decided not to drink.' Giving a reason can sometimes help: 'I have a game tomorrow' or 'I do not like how it makes me feel.' Suggesting alternatives redirects the situation: 'Let's go get food instead.' Using the buddy system means agreeing with a friend beforehand to support each other's choices. Buying time with 'Maybe later' can help you exit without confrontation. Blame an external factor: 'My parents would ground me for life.' Humour can deflect pressure without creating tension. Sometimes the best strategy is simply leaving the situation. Having multiple strategies means you can adapt to different circumstances.

explicatoryContent.heading: Being a Good Friend
explicatoryContent.text: Supporting friends who might be struggling with substance use requires care and skill. If you are worried about a friend, choose a private moment to express your concern without judgment. Use 'I' statements like 'I've noticed you seem different lately and I'm worried about you' rather than accusations. Listen more than you talk. Do not try to force them to change or give ultimatums, as this often backfires. Let them know you care and that help is available. If you are seriously concerned about their safety, it is okay to tell a trusted adult even if your friend asks you not to - sometimes getting help is more important than keeping a secret. You cannot fix someone else's problems, but you can be a supportive presence.

C.levelDescription: Sound understanding of the cognitive and social psychology of decision-making, with ability to analyse situations and apply contextually appropriate strategies.

explicatoryContent.heading: The Psychology of Decision-Making
explicatoryContent.text: Decision-making involves cognitive processes that can be influenced by various factors. Dual-process theory suggests we have two modes of thinking: System 1 (fast, automatic, emotional) and System 2 (slow, deliberate, rational). In high-pressure social situations, System 1 often dominates, leading to quick decisions based on emotion rather than careful reasoning. Alcohol and drugs further impair System 2 functioning. This explains why people sometimes make choices in the moment that they later regret. Understanding this psychology means we can prepare in advance when System 2 is engaged, making plans and decisions before we are in high-pressure situations. Pre-commitment strategies, like deciding beforehand not to drink at a particular event, help because the decision is already made.

explicatoryContent.heading: Group Dynamics and Social Contexts
explicatoryContent.text: Different social contexts create different pressures. In-group identity (feeling part of a group) strongly influences behaviour; we are more likely to conform to in-group norms. Social hierarchies affect who has influence; higher-status individuals have more power to set norms. Diffusion of responsibility occurs in groups where individuals feel less personally accountable. Deindividuation, where people lose their sense of individual identity in a crowd, can lead to behaviour they would not normally engage in. Pluralistic ignorance is when everyone privately disagrees with a norm but goes along because they assume others support it - this is common with drinking norms where most people overestimate how much their peers drink and approve of drinking. Understanding these dynamics helps us recognise when we might be influenced and make more conscious choices.

explicatoryContent.heading: Advanced Communication Strategies
explicatoryContent.text: Effective communication in challenging situations requires social and emotional intelligence. Assertiveness involves expressing your needs and boundaries clearly while respecting others - it is different from aggression (violating others' rights) and passivity (not expressing your needs). Non-verbal communication matters; maintaining eye contact, standing confidently, and using a calm tone reinforces your message. Active listening shows respect for others while maintaining your position. Negotiation skills help find solutions that work for everyone. De-escalation techniques can defuse tense situations. It is also important to know when a situation is beyond your ability to handle and when to exit or seek help. These communication skills apply not just to drug-related situations but to all challenging interpersonal contexts.

explicatoryContent.heading: Bystander Intervention and Positive Norms
explicatoryContent.text: Being an active bystander means taking action when you see harmful situations developing, rather than staying passive. The bystander effect describes how people are less likely to help when others are present, each assuming someone else will act. Overcoming this requires recognising the situation as a problem, feeling personally responsible, and knowing how to help. The 5Ds of bystander intervention provide options: Direct (directly addressing the situation), Distract (creating a diversion), Delegate (getting help from others), Delay (checking in with the person afterward), and Document (recording if appropriate and safe). Beyond individual intervention, we can help shift group norms by modelling positive behaviours, correcting misperceptions about how common drug use is, and creating environments where healthy choices are the easy choices. Young people have significant power to shape the social norms within their peer groups.

D.levelDescription: Comprehensive understanding of the interplay between individual cognition, social psychology, and environmental factors in decision-making, with capacity to critically evaluate intervention approaches.

explicatoryContent.heading: Models of Health Behaviour
explicatoryContent.text: Understanding why people make health decisions requires examining multiple theoretical models. The Health Belief Model suggests behaviour is influenced by perceived susceptibility (How likely is harm?), perceived severity (How bad would it be?), perceived benefits (What do I gain from changing?), and perceived barriers (What makes change hard?). Self-efficacy, or confidence in one's ability to change, is crucial. The Theory of Planned Behaviour adds subjective norms (What do important others think?) and perceived behavioural control (How much control do I have?). The Transtheoretical Model describes stages of change from precontemplation through to maintenance, recognising that change is a process, not an event. Motivational interviewing is a counselling approach that helps people move through these stages by exploring ambivalence without confrontation. These models inform how we design interventions and how we understand why some people change behaviour while others do not.

explicatoryContent.heading: Socioecological Approaches
explicatoryContent.text: The socioecological model recognises that individual behaviour is shaped by multiple nested levels of influence: individual (knowledge, attitudes, skills), interpersonal (family, friends, peers), organisational (schools, workplaces), community (local norms, resources), and societal (laws, policies, cultural values). Effective prevention addresses multiple levels rather than focusing solely on individual choice. At the individual level, this includes building knowledge and skills. At the interpersonal level, positive peer norms and family communication. At the organisational level, school policies and supportive environments. At the community level, availability of services and local regulations. At the societal level, advertising restrictions, pricing policies, and cultural narratives. This framework helps explain why individual-focused approaches alone are often insufficient and why addressing structural and environmental factors matters.

explicatoryContent.heading: Evaluating Prevention Programs
explicatoryContent.text: Not all prevention programs are equally effective, and critical evaluation is essential. Key questions include: Is there evidence from rigorous studies (randomised controlled trials, longitudinal research)? What outcomes were measured and how? Were effects maintained over time? Did the program work for different populations? What was the mechanism of change? Fear-based approaches that emphasise dangers have generally been found ineffective and can sometimes increase curiosity. Information-only approaches have limited impact on behaviour. More effective programs are interactive, build skills, address social influences, and are delivered over multiple sessions. Life Skills Training and the Good Behaviour Game are examples of programs with strong evidence. Implementation quality matters; even good programs fail when poorly delivered. Cost-effectiveness analysis helps determine whether resources are well spent. Healthy scepticism of programs that promise dramatic results without strong evidence is warranted.

explicatoryContent.heading: Peer-Led Health Promotion
explicatoryContent.text: Peer-led approaches leverage the influence that young people have on each other. Research suggests peers can be more credible sources of health information than adults for certain topics. Effective peer education involves careful selection and training of peer leaders, clear role definitions, ongoing support and supervision, and realistic expectations. Peer leaders should be seen as credible by the target audience, which may mean selecting diverse leaders including those who are not just 'model students.' Activities might include leading discussions, creating media campaigns, modelling positive behaviours, and providing informal support. Challenges include ensuring accuracy of information, managing boundaries, and avoiding burnout. Peer approaches work best as part of comprehensive strategies that also address environmental factors and involve adults in supportive roles. Young people can also contribute to program design and evaluation, ensuring interventions are relevant and acceptable to their intended audience.

E.levelDescription: Advanced critical analysis of the psychological, social, and structural determinants of decision-making, with capacity for original synthesis and designing innovative intervention approaches.

explicatoryContent.heading: Advanced Social Cognition
explicatoryContent.text: Social cognitive theory, developed by Albert Bandura, integrates behavioural, cognitive, and environmental factors in understanding human behaviour. Key concepts include reciprocal determinism (behaviour, cognition, and environment continuously influence each other), observational learning (learning by watching others), and self-regulation (managing one's own behaviour through goal-setting and self-monitoring). More recent developments include research on social identity and how group memberships shape cognition and behaviour. Self-affirmation theory suggests that affirming core values can buffer against defensive responses to health information. Implementation intentions (specific if-then plans) can bridge the intention-behaviour gap. Construal level theory examines how psychological distance affects decision-making; we think more abstractly about distant events and more concretely about near ones. These advanced theories provide tools for designing more sophisticated interventions that account for the complexity of human psychology.

explicatoryContent.heading: Neuroscience Meets Social Context
explicatoryContent.text: Emerging research at the intersection of neuroscience and social psychology provides new insights into decision-making. Social neuroscience examines how brain processes underlie social behaviour. The adolescent brain shows heightened sensitivity to social rewards (like peer approval) and to immediate rewards over delayed ones, helping explain risk-taking behaviour in social contexts. Stress affects brain function in ways that can impair decision-making and increase reliance on habitual responses. The prefrontal cortex, crucial for executive function, is still developing during adolescence and is affected by both stress and substance use. Neuroimaging studies show that peer presence activates reward-related brain regions in adolescents more than adults. However, the brain also shows remarkable plasticity, and positive social relationships and environments can support healthy development. This neuroscience-informed perspective neither excuses poor decisions nor reduces complex behaviour to brain chemistry, but it provides important context for understanding and intervention.

explicatoryContent.heading: Structural Interventions and Policy
explicatoryContent.text: While individual and interpersonal approaches are important, structural interventions that change environments and policies can have population-level impact. Availability policies control where and when substances can be accessed (outlet density, trading hours). Pricing policies like taxation influence consumption, particularly among young people and heavy users. Marketing restrictions reduce exposure to pro-substance messaging. Default options and choice architecture can make healthy choices easier. School policies that balance prevention with supportive responses to substance use affect both norms and outcomes for students who need help. Structural interventions often face political resistance because they constrain commercial interests or individual liberty, requiring effective advocacy. Evidence suggests that comprehensive approaches combining individual, community, and policy interventions are most effective. Critical analysis involves examining not just effectiveness but also equity impacts - some policies may benefit some groups while burdening others.

explicatoryContent.heading: Youth Advocacy and Participatory Design
explicatoryContent.text: Young people have the right to participate in decisions that affect them, including health policies and programs. Participatory approaches involve young people not just as recipients but as partners in designing, implementing, and evaluating interventions. Youth participatory action research (YPAR) involves young people in identifying issues, collecting data, and developing solutions. Student voice initiatives give young people formal roles in school governance. Youth advocacy involves speaking up for policy changes at local, state, or national levels. Effective youth participation requires genuine power-sharing, not tokenistic involvement. Adults play supportive roles providing resources, training, and access while respecting young people's autonomy and perspectives. Young people bring unique insights about their own lives and can identify issues and solutions that adults might miss. Participation also has developmental benefits, building leadership skills and civic engagement. Critics note challenges including representation (whose voices are heard?), capacity building, and sustainability. Nonetheless, participatory approaches represent an ethical commitment to respecting young people's agency and rights.

explicatoryContent.heading: Designing Innovative Approaches
explicatoryContent.text: Innovation in health promotion involves applying new technologies, insights, and methods while maintaining evidence-based principles. Digital interventions (apps, games, social media campaigns) can reach young people in their digital environments but require careful design to be engaging and effective. Gamification applies game design elements to health behaviours. Personalisation uses data to tailor messages and interventions to individuals. Co-design involves target audiences in developing interventions. Design thinking provides a structured approach to innovation: empathise (understand users), define (frame the problem), ideate (generate solutions), prototype (test quickly), and iterate (refine based on feedback). Scaling effective innovations requires attention to implementation science - understanding what makes interventions work in real-world conditions. A key principle is that innovation should complement, not replace, proven approaches. Novel methods need rigorous evaluation before widespread adoption. Young people can be innovators themselves, bringing creativity and digital literacy to developing new approaches.
